item.title: Dungeons & Dragons: Best Bows, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Bows in D&D lack variety compared to swords, but special arrows can add utility and new damage types for players.
  • New supplement books bring shiny new bows like Dragon Wing Bow, Starcrossed Bow, and Bow of Conflagration to the game.
  • Legendary bows like Oathbow, Bow of Melodies, and Longbow of the Healing Hearth offer unique advantages and powers for players.

Dungeons & Dragons is the role-playing game that invented the concept, and something that players have always loved about the game is the variety of gear they can find and the stories behind some of these weapons. Not to say that there aren’t fantastic options for characters that enjoy a bit of range, but compared to swords or daggers, there tend to be fewer bows in the D&D universe compared to other weapons.

With the recent changes in D&D content, ranged combat has gotten some love from the creators. There are several new weapon options, ranging from whimsical to very powerful, and of course, any new content has to be first approved by the DM of the game.

Characters that utilize bows or short bows should keep in mind that they can also make use of special arrows, of which there are plenty in the game. While a great bow can give a nice boost to damage and attack rolls, special arrows can expand the player’s utility range and allow for different types of damage.

Updated on January 18, 2025, by Kristy Ambrose: As great as finding a stack of gold is in D&D, nothing beats getting a brand-new item or a weapon to boost a character's abilities even more. Ranged DPS has become a more popular build, with classes like Rangers and Rogues taking on the role of a sniper or sneak-attack expert. Bows in D&D cover a few different types and include longbows, short bows, hunting bows, and some other creative varieties.

14 Taulmaril

The Forgotten Realms

  • Stats: +3 to attacks and damage, the Keen property, and the Force ability.

Also known as the Heartseeker, this legendary longbow appears in the Forgotten Realms, specifically in the stories about Drizzt Do'Urden. The bow was the property of Catti-Brie, one of the Drow's most loyal companions, and he kept it after her death and even after her reincarnation when she was less of a ranged fighter and more of a spellcaster.

Taulmaril had the usual bonuses of an elven-made short bow in addition to Keen, which means improved sharpness, and Force, which allows the wielder to add a blast of magical force to each attack. Catti-Brie acquired it through her connection with Clan Battlehammer, the Dwarves that took her in after her parents were killed.

13 Red-Feather Bow

Humblewood Campaign Setting

  • Stats: +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls, use the arrow to "see" as a Bonus Action

The Red-Feather bow has been introduced in the Humblewood campaign setting . While not incredibly powerful, it can be a very useful tool for scouting and tracking. From high-octane chases to finding that one pesky enemy that got away, players can find plenty of utility for it.

The bow allows the wielder to see through the arrow for a minute after it has been fired. On top of that, if the arrow hits a creature, the wielder can see through that creature’s eyes. The effect can be truly game-changing, given the right scenario.

12 Dragon Wing Bow

Fizban's Treasury of Dragons

  • Stats: Generic Variant (crossbow/longbow/shortbow), Rare quality

Every such weapon looks like the wing of a particular dragon, but it’s far more than just great visual design. Depending on the type of the dragon, the weapon gives an additional 1d6 damage corresponding to the dragon’s breath; lightning for Blue, fire for Red, cold for White, and so on.

If a character does not load an arrow, the bow produces one itself. After connecting with the target or missing, the projectile is immediately destroyed. It’s a great bow that shouldn’t be too hard to acquire, and a special damage type is always great.

11 Starcrossed Bow

The Book of Many Things

  • Stats: +2 bonus, Generic Variant (crossbow/longbow/shortbow), Rare quality

The Starcrossed Bow is a beautiful weapon that shoots its own projectiles made of light. It’s already neat not having to worry about ammunition, but the bow also comes with a nice +2 bonus for attacks and damage. For its rarity, this would already be great, but on top of that, the weapon has a special property.

The bow has three charges, replenishable at dawn. Players can use up a charge whenever they successfully hit an enemy, and cause a flash of bright light. Enemies in the area have to make a saving throw or become blinded until the end of the player’s next turn.

10 Bow of Conflagration

The Book of Many Things

  • Stats: Generic Variant (longbow/shortbow), extra 1d6 damage per shot, Rare quality

This bow is perfect for the pyromaniac in the group, and there’s always one. Aside from the extra 1d6 damage per shot, the fiery arrows that the bow shoots also set anything flammable ablaze, including enemies.

As a result, creatures that are burning will also take 1d6 fire damage at the start of their turn, until they expend an action to extinguish the flames. It is a great weapon with good damage that can quickly turn into a catastrophe in the wrong (or right) hands. Suddenly, DMs have to think a lot more about fire safety in any town or building their players walk into.

9 Longbow of Melodies

The Book of Many Things

  • Stats: Martial weapon, Very Rare, +1 bonus to attacks if proficient in Performance, another +2 with Expertise, the abilities Melody of Precision and Melody of Persuasion

This curious-looking bow has multiple strings, somewhat resembling a lyre. As a character loads an arrow, they can strum the strings, imbuing the shot with magical music and gaining additional properties. Melody of Precision adds yet another +1 bonus and Melody of Persuasion adds Thunder damage to the attack.

If the wielder is proficient with Performance, they gain a +1 bonus to attacks. If they have Expertise, the bonus is increased to +2. Alternatively, the wielder can put a little extra into the shot, adding thunder damage based on their charisma modifier. Overall, this is a fantastic choice for a particular Bard subclass or a very expressive Ranger of Fighter.

8 Oathbow

D&D Basic Rulebook (2014)

  • Stats: Martial Weapon, Very Rare, the Slow property, +3d6 piercing damage

The Oathbow is perhaps one of the most famous legendary bows among players and for good reason. The weapon allows the wielder to pick a Sworn Enemy, and the bow will do its best to assist the owner in defeating their foe.

Once a new Sworn Enemy is chosen, the wielder has Advantage on attacks with the bow against that enemy and completely ignores any cover aside from Total. On top of that, every hit does an additional 3d6 piercing damage nd Slow reduces the target's movement by ten feet per turn. It is a great offensive weapon, one that is specifically designed to let no one get away.

7 Bow Of Melodies

The Book of Many Things

  • Stats: Generic Variant (longbow/shortbow), Very Rare,bonuses are based on Performance and damage is based on Charisma

Everything about this bow screams Bard. The weapon is fashioned after a musical instrument. The bonuses from it are given to those who have Proficiency or Expertise in Performance, and the damage is based on Charisma.

This is a fantastic choice for any combat bard who could never quite choose between their lute and their love for archery. Nonetheless, the weapon can fit quite a few archetypes and subclasses, giving players even more freedom when creating their next character. And the role-playing potential is fantastic to have. Will they play a shredding solo, or shoot the suspicious duke?

6 Longbow of Throne's Command

The Book of Many Things

  • Stats: Martial Weapon, Very Rare, 5 spellcasting charges, +1 to attacks

As per the name, the Longbow of Throne's Command gives the wielder quite a lot of power over other creatures. While this might not be the most directly powerful weapon, it comes with a number of spells the wielder can use to control and command their enemies.

The bow does come with a +1 bonus to attacks and allows the wielder to spend the weapon’s charges to cast the following spells: Command, Zone of Truth, Compulsion, Banishment, and Dominate Person. It’s a great weapon to add to an arsenal, giving the owner quite a lot of utility on the battlefield.

5 Bow of Four Seasons

Timmmi's Treasure Vault

  • Stats: Longbow, Very Rare, infused with different powers depending on the season,+2d8 damage

This weapon allows the wielder to deal four different kinds of damage based on the gems infused with it; lightning, fire, magical bludgeoning, and cold. As part of their attack, players can create an arrow of an element, dealing an extra 2d8 damage on a hit.

It is a powerful and versatile tool that can fit into almost any build. The only downside is the weapon’s heavy property, meaning that smaller characters will struggle with using it. Unless, of course, the DM waives that part and lets the goblin unleash chaos with a miniature version,

4 Longbow of the Healing Hearth

Bigby Presents - Glory of the Giants

  • Stats: Martial Weapon, Legendary quality, +3 bonus to attacks, the ability to create food and water and the extra power of Curative Arrow

This is an incredible bow with both incredible destructive power and effective healing capabilities. On their turn, players can choose whether to attack their enemies with a +3 bonus to attacks or use one of the few healing abilities that the bow has.

Players can utilize a Curative Arrow, which automatically hits anyone within 150 range, and allows the target to immediately utilize a Hit Die, and add the wielder’s Wisdom modifier. The bow also allows the caster to spend the weapon’s charges and cast Create Food and Water, Warding Bond, or Guardian of Faith.

3 Ascendant Dragon's Wrath Longbow

Fizban's Treasury Of Dragons

  • Stats: Martial Weapon, Uncommon to Legendary quality, +3 bonus to attacks, 3d6 extra damage of the dragon’s type, AoE damage with a critical hit

This is the final form of the Dragon’s Wrath Longbow, which starts as Uncommon and goes all the way to Legendary Rarity. At this point, the weapon becomes a draconic menace, allowing the wielder to channel and even mimic a Dragon’s Breath.

The bow has a +3 bonus to attacks, 3d6 extra damage of the dragon’s type, and an AOE 5 damage around the target on a critical hit. On top of all of that, once per day, the wielder can unleash the bow’s full power, dealing a devastating 12d6 damage in a massive cone.

2 Protector of the Dryads

The Forgotten Realms

  • Stats: +2 or +3 to attack and damage rolls

This bow originally came from Gulthmere Forest in Vilhon Reach, and it was crafted by the Dryads of these woods to take revenge on the Orcs that were chopping down their trees. For a while the famous bow was possessed by Hannable the White, who used it to slay a whole tribe of Orcs after they killed a sacred tree, killing its Dryad.

The Protector of the Dryads was also called the Eagle Bow, and in the D&D stats, it has a +3, but a plus two in the video games in which it appears. Those who have played the first Baldur's Gate games might have seen it in the hands of the assassin Marek, and once the party kills him, it can be looted from his corpse.

1 Ephixis, Bow of Nylea

Mythic Odysseys of Theros

  • Stats: Shortbow, Artifact, +3 bonus to attacks, critical hit on a roll of 19

At the moment, this is the only Artifact-level bow that exists within the official rulebooks. This is an absolutely devastating, nature-based weapon that comes loaded with extra abilities and features. Besides the +3 bonus to attacks, the weapon also has no Disadvantage on the second range, and also critically hits on a roll of 19.

Aside from other randomly assigned beneficial properties, the bow also comes with its own quiver, with 4 special arrows that replenish at dusk. Every arrow is tied to a yearly season and has its own special properties and abilities. There's even a special way to destroy It using the black oak tree of Asphodel during the equinox.

item.title: Pokemon GO: Shadow Registeel Raid Guide - Weaknesses, Counters & More
item.description:
As part of the live-service format that Pokemon GO follows, each new season that comes and passes through the game brings a series of events and in-game celebrations for players to enjoy. As part of these events and general ongoing seasonal changes, the types of Pokemon that Trainers can encounter as Raid Bosses will change, bringing a variety of different specimens for players to go up against and potentially obtain.

Raids offer quite a bit of variety, with 1 Star Raids usually involving first form/basic Pokemon and more common wild encounters, 2-4 Star Raids involving evolved Pokemon and those with greater stats, 5-Star Raids involving Legendaries and Mythical Pokemon, Mega Raids involving Mega Evolutions, and Shadow Raids consisting of Shadow Pokemon. Shadow Registeel is one of many Pokemon known to appear in Shadow Raids, with this boss making a return in the Dual Destiny Season. If Trainers are looking to take on this Raid boss in battle, they will need to consider the key weaknesses and Resistances, as well as the best potential counters - all of which have been outlined in the guide below.

Pokemon GO: Shadow Registeel Weakness And Resistances

In Pokemon GO , Shadow Registeel is a pure Steel Type Legendary monster with a maximum CP of 2766 and a stat spread of 143 ATK, 285 DEF, and 190 STA . Duel to Registeel's Type has several key resistances and weaknesses for players to consider prior to going up against one in battle.

Shadow Registeel has many resistances to Pokemon of the Poison, Steel, Rock, Bug, Dragon, Psychic, Fairy, Flying, Ice, Grass, and Normal Types - so Trainers should avoid utilizing monsters who utilize such attributes when possible. However, Registeel is also weak to Ground, Fire, and Fighting Types, so Trainers should highly prioritize such monsters to give themselves the best advantage in Shadow Registeel Raids.

Lastly, Registeel receives improved power through the Weather Boost mechanic when battling in Snow Weather, so Trainers may wish to avoid Raids under such circumstances, if possible.

Best Shadow Registeel Raid Counters In Pokemon GO

When considering the best counters for Shadow Registeel during Pokemon GO Raids, players will need to keep Registeel's key weaknesses and resistances in mind, and opt to utilize monsters who wield Types or powerful attacks that share attributes with Types Registeel is weak to. Players may also wish to utilize STAB - Same Type Attack Bonus, by using a Pokemon whose attacks share a Type with the monster itself, gaining additional damage.

item.title: TikTok No Longer Works in the US
item.description:
Summary

  • TikTok stopped working in the US on Saturday, January 18.
  • This is due to the TikTok ban that was recently upheld by the Supreme Court.
  • President Trump has indicated that he may try to bring the app back, but no return date has been announced.

The wildly successful social media/video app TikTok no longer works in the US as of 10:00pm CST on Saturday, January 18. TikTok, the successor to Musical.ly, exploded in popularity during the pandemic, quickly becoming one of the world's most-used apps. Hundreds of millions of individuals use TikTok on a daily basis, but unfortunately for its fans, the app has been a political target for years now.

TikTok was developed by the Chinese company ByteDance, which has been accused by some politicians of collecting user data for the Chinese government. TikTok itself has vehemently denied these accusations, but that hasn't stopped the case against it from going all the way to the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court came to a unanimous decision that the proposed TikTok ban could proceed. President Biden indicated that his administration would not enforce the ban, and incoming President Trump has suggested that he may do something to keep the app online. Despite this, TikTok is no longer available in the US at the time of this writing.

TikTok stopped working at about 10:00pm CST on Saturday, January 18. The TikTok ban in the US has made the app unusable, meaning that users can no longer scroll through their For Your Page, access their saved videos, or talk with their friends. When trying to use TikTok right now in the US, users are greeted with a message that says, "Sorry, TikTok isn't available right now. A law banning TikTok has been enacted in the U.S. Unfortunately, that means you can't use TikTok for now. We are fortunate that President Trump has indicated that he will work with us on a solution to reinstate TikTok once he takes office. Please stay tuned!"

Is TikTok Down Right Now?

  • TikTok no longer works in the US as of January 18.

Prior to TikTok being banned, one solution proposed was for ByteDance to sell the app to an American company. That hasn't happened, and so it's unclear what solution will be reached to reinstate the app, assuming Trump does attempt to do so. In the meantime, angry TikTok users have found their own ways to protest the ban. There have been in-person protests, but users have also started downloading Rednote en masse. Rednote, for the initiated, is very similar to TikTok, but it is targeted directly at users in China.

Sorry, TikTok isn't available right now. A law banning TikTok has been enacted in the U.S. Unfortunately, that means you can't use TikTok for now. We are fortunate that President Trump has indicated that he will work with us on a solution to reinstate TikTok once he takes office. Please stay tuned!

Whether Trump is able to bring TikTok back remains to be seen, but it will definitely be interesting to see what happens in the coming days. In the meantime, MrBeast has teased that he's had talks with billionaires about the possibility of buying TikTok himself, but it's hard to say if something like that will actually happen. For now, TikTok users in the US can't use the app, and no return date has been announced .

item.title: 9 Best RPGs That Prioritize Projectiles In Combat
item.description:
Summary

  • Western RPGs blend engaging combat & rich narratives effectively.
  • RPGs like The Outer Worlds, Wasteland 3, & Persona 5 merge guns with strategic gameplay.
  • Games like Fallout 4, Warframe, & Cyberpunk 2077 offer rich weapon customization.

When most people think of RPGs , they picture high fantasy with swords and spellcraft. However, the RPG genre has grown and evolved a lot since its inception, and it encompasses a lot of aspects and hallmarks from the rest of the gaming industry.

This includes firearms and other projectile-based weapons. While the thoughtful, strategic gameplay of most RPGs would seem to be mutually exclusive with the hectic chaos of a gunfight, there have been plenty of games that skillfully combine the two. These are the best RPGs that prioritize long-range projectile combat.

9 The Outer Worlds

A Twisted Future

Obsidian's irreverent space RPG brings players to a futuristic world where capitalism has grown out of control, resulting in shabby, broken-down settlements running on indentured labor. In the player's quest to deliver this distant solar system from its oppressive rulers, they'll accumulate an ever-growing armory of increasingly outlandish weapons.

The weapon catalog in The Outer Worlds encompasses everything fans would expect from a bombastic sci-fi adventure, from conventional rifles to outlandish laser weapons. Players can also acquire numerous "science weapons" with bizarre additional effects, such as shrinking or even mind-controlling enemies.

8 Wasteland 3

Apocalyptic Tactics

The Wasteland franchise isn't as prominent in modern times as the Fallout games that were inspired by it, but 2020's Wasteland 3 is no less enjoyable for tactical RPG fans. This squad-based adventure takes players to post-apocalyptic Colorado on a quest to resolve a bloody familial dispute taking place among the region's rulers.

Wasteland 3 players have countless options in how they customize and outfit their squad of rangers, dipping into a vast arsenal of firearms in order to adequately face any challenge that might await them. With the addition of environmental effects and player vehicles, no two fights in Wasteland 3 will ever play out the same way.

7 Persona 5 Royal

Changing Hearts At Gunpoint

It's not terribly common to see ranged weapons in turn-based JRPGs, but Persona 5 is a particularly illustrious example of this. Damage from firearms is a distinct damage type in the game that players can exploit in fights to expose enemy weaknesses, and each party member has their own distinctive type of firearm with its own unique properties.

By increasing one's bond with the enigmatic Airsoft Shop owner, Iwai, players can upgrade their projectile weapons even further, adding modifiers and special effects to their shots. The unique properties of guns and ammo in the game's mystical cognitive realm means firearms are always a powerful option in combat.

6 Warframe

Fighting For The Future

The sci-fi MMO RPG Warframe takes place in the far future, as a race of powerful alien warriors struggles to survive against the numerous dangerous factions who have inherited a long-dead Earth. Players' titular Warframes serve as combat units that they guide in battle, and they can customize these rigs with a variety of weapons for different combat situations.

The game's high-speed gunplay and complex storyline have snared a lot of fans, and the fact that the basic experience is free-to-play is a definite selling point. In terms of accessibility, Warframe is one of the best gun-based RPGs on the market.

5 Fallout 4

Scrapping For A Fight

Bethesda's Fallout 4 boasts one of the most robust weapon crafting systems in the industry. Fans can collect junk and scrap from ruins throughout the wasteland and bring it home to upgrade and modify their guns in a variety of ways. Players can add silencers, rapid-fire modifications, scopes, and even alternate handles to make their guns their own.

In addition to the elaborate modifications players can craft for themselves, there is a wide variety of unique and bizarre weapons for players to encounter in the wild. From the potent freezing potential of the Cryolator to the preposterous Broadsider, a hand-mounted naval cannon, fans can bring a lot of firepower to a fight.

4 Remnant 2

Gun Souls

The Remnant franchise presents the dark future of humanity driven to the brink of ruin by exposure to alien forces from other realities. Players in Remnant 2 must take up arms to protect their struggling civilization from godly threats outside the known universe itself.

Remnant 2 made a name for itself by combining third-person shooter mechanics with the punishing action RPG elements from the infamous soulslike genre. Players must contend with tight resources and massive, powerful attacks as they fire away at powerful monsters.

3 Cyberpunk 2077

A Futuristic Firefight

The world of Cyberpunk 2077 depicts a culture increasingly submerged in consumerism and corporate greed. As social stratification grows, violence becomes all the more commonplace, to the point that vending machines throughout Night City dispense 3D-printed guns for citizens' protection. In order to succeed in this game, players will need to come prepared.

Cyberpunk 2077 presents a massive arsenal of weapons, with a tier system separating the cream of the crop. To heighten the futuristic nature of the game, many firearms have fanciful upgrades, from corrosive or fire damage to target-seeking projectiles.

2 Bloodborne

Blasting Back The Horrors

FromSoftware's iconic gothic horror soulslike changed a lot from the basic Dark Souls formula. One of the most striking new features was the addition of flintlock pistols and various other contemporary firearms. These guns rely on Quicksilver Bullets, a new resource players will have to manage as they confront the horrors within Yharnam.

Bloodborne 's guns function quite distinctly in combat. With perfect timing, fans can unleash a blast of lead to halt an enemy's attack and open them up for a devastating counterattack. A well-timed gunshot can be the difference between life and death, for hunter and beast alike.

1 Horizon Forbidden West

Big Game Hunting

The deadly robotic beasts of Horizon Forbidden West require skill and strategy to take down. While Aloy does have a rather potent melee option, swinging wildly will rarely turn out well for her. Careful and clever use of ranged weapons is a much more reliable approach.

There are ten weapon types in Horizon Forbidden West , each of which has different strengths and weaknesses when facing a certain type of machine. Each weapon also comes with different ammo types, offering a variety of elemental damage options to exploit weaknesses. Aloy will have to aim carefully and plan strategically to survive in this hostile world.

item.title: Bitlife: How to Complete the Baby Boomer Challenge
item.description:
Another Bitlife challenge is here. This time, it’s the Baby Boomer challenge. It started on Jan 18 and lasts for four days.

In the Baby Boomer challenge, your character will travel around the world and have lots of babies. Here’s how you can complete it.

How to Complete Baby Boomer in Bitlife

Here are the steps fans will need to complete:

  • Be Born a Female in New York
  • Become a Nurse
  • Have 5+ Babies in New York
  • Have 5+ Babies in Argentina
  • Have 5+ Babies in Italy.

How to Be Born a Female in New York

To get things started, Bitlife players will need to make a new character. So go to the main menu and start a new life with a female character. Choose the United States as your character’s country and New York as their birthplace.

As you age, stay away from crime because it will help you become a nurse and move to other countries for your next steps. Furthermore, try to keep your smarts high, as it will help with becoming a nurse.

How to Become a Nurse in Bitlife

First, you need to get a nursing degree after your secondary school. Try to get a scholarship, or you can take a student loan or ask your parents for money. Keeping your smart stats high can help you get a scholarship.

After that, apply to nursing school for a 2-year program. Make sure you have enough money for tuition if you don’t get a scholarship. Once you graduate, you will need to go to the full time job section in the ‘Occupation’ menu and apply for the ‘Associate Nurse’ position.

How to Have Babies in New York, Argentina, and Italy

Now it’s time to travel and have babies. You’re in New York for now, so it’s a good idea to start having kids early. Your character needs to have 15 in total, so try to have some kids before they become a nurse to get ahead.

You need a lot of babies, so the Golden Pacifier feature can be really useful. It allows you to have twins or triplets, but it’s not free. To have a baby, you will need to use the Hookup option in the Activities menu, and make sure you don’t use any protection.

After having five kids in New York, you should move to Argentina and Italy through the Emigrate option in the ‘Activities’ section . If you don’t find these countries, restart the app.

Bitizens will also need plenty of money to cover the kids and travel. Marrying someone rich can help with that. Once you have five kids in both countries, the challenge will be completed.
